comments:
Not sure what gives rise to this. I wasn't really doing anything with web services (intentionally) ... I just imported a huge set of semi-random test files into a dynamic web project.

Found on final version of 1.5.1. 


!ENTRY org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.webservice.ui 4 0 2006-09-26 09:05:20.000
!MESSAGE org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder incompatible with org.eclipse.core.resources.IFile
!STACK 0
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder incompatible with org.eclipse.core.resources.IFile
        at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.webservice.helper.WebServicesManager.getWorkspaceWSILFiles(WebServicesManager.java:695)
        at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.webservice.helper.WebServicesManager.getWsdlServicesFromWorkspaceWSILs(WebServicesManager.java:437)
        at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.webservice.helper.WebServicesManager.getExternalWSDLServices(WebServicesManager.java:430)
        at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.webservice.WebServiceViewerSynchronization.indexWebServices(WebServiceViewerSynchronization.java:187)
        at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.webservice.WebServiceViewerSynchronization.access$0(WebServiceViewerSynchronization.java:150)
        at org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.webservice.WebServiceViewerSynchronization$WebServiceIndexJob.run(WebServiceViewerSynchronization.java:234)
        at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

This is part of the J2EE extension to the Project Explorer that contributes the "Web Services" branch. This looks like code that is hunting down Web service references in WSIL files from the workspace. Over to J2EE Tools.
